content:
Introduction

The ovary is composed of the surface epithelium, ovarian cortex (containing connective tissue stroma and follicles with oocytes), and the inner medulla (containing major blood vessels and connective tissue).  Ovarian masses can arise from each of these ovarian tissues due to various processes, including hormonal stimulation, infection/inflammation, and neoplasias.



Ovarian masses are common gynecologic findings that can be discovered incidentally on imaging or during the evaluation of pelvic pain, bloating, or menstrual irregularities.  Most masses are benign, but their evaluation requires a systematic approach to differentiate between functional cysts, benign tumors, and ovarian cancer.

Common ovarian masses

Benign ovarian masses



  • Functional cysts:  Hormonal variations within the menstrual cycle lead to the growth and development of an ovarian follicle in preparation for ovulation (
    figure 1
    ).  Following ovulation, the continued growth and distension of this follicle can lead to fluid-filled follicular or corpus luteum cysts.  Functional cysts usually resolve by the next menstrual cycle.
  • Pregnancy-related ovarian masses:  hCG stimulation (eg, normal pregnancy, multifetal pregnancy, gestational trophoblastic disease, ovarian hyperstimulation) can lead to the development of theca-lutein cysts (multiseptated ovarian cysts) or luteomas (solid ovarian masses).  These masses tend to be bilateral and can secrete androgens, causing maternal hirsutism or virilization.
  • Endometriomas (
    figure 2
    ):  Ectopic endometrial tissue can implant on the ovary and bleed, creating cysts filled with thick, dark fluid (chocolate cysts) (
    image 1
    ).
  • Tuboovarian abscesses:  These typically occur as a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease and appear as complex adnexal masses, typically associated with fever and adnexal and cervical motion tenderness.
  • Serous or mucinous cystadenomas:  These benign neoplasias arise from the ovarian surface epithelium; they are typically thin-walled cysts that can grow very large.
  • Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) (
    image 2
    ):  These benign tumors are composed of various cell types, including ectodermal, mesodermal, and endodermal elements; grossly may contain hair, teeth, and sebaceous material.
  • Ovarian fibromas:  These are solid, benign tumors are composed of fibroblasts.

Malignant ovarian masses



Malignant ovarian masses are classified by the type of tissue from which they arise (

figure 3
):



  • Epithelial ovarian cancers:  Include various histologic subtypes (eg, serous, mucinous, clear cell, endometrioid).  The most common type of ovarian cancer, epithelial ovarian cancer tends to occur in older women and is often diagnosed at advanced stages.
  • Germ cell tumors:  Include immature teratomas, dysgerminomas, and yolk sac tumors; they tend to occur in women age <30.  Elevated tumor markers include hCG, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).
  • Sex cord–stromal tumors:  Include granulosa cell tumors and Sertoli-Leydig tumors.  Granulosa tumors cause symptoms of estrogen excess (eg, precocious puberty, abnormal uterine bleeding).  Sertoli-Leydig tumors cause symptoms of androgen excess (eg, clitoromegaly, hirsutism, deepening of the voice).
  • Metastases:  Involve the spread of malignant cells to the ovary from a different primary cancer (eg, gastrointestinal tract [Krukenberg tumor], breast).

Risk factors



Risk factors for benign ovarian masses include:



  • Reproductive age.
  • Ovulation induction or ovarian hyperstimulation.
  • Tamoxifen use.
  • Use of an intrauterine device or contraceptive implant.


Risk factors for malignant ovarian masses include:



  • Postmenopausal age.
  • Hereditary cancer syndromes (eg, BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations, Lynch syndrome).
  • Family history of ovarian cancer.
  • Endometriosis (increased risk for endometrioid and clear cell ovarian cancers).
  • Nulliparity.

Clinical presentation



Ovarian masses are often asymptomatic because the abdominopelvic cavity conceals masses arising from the relatively free-floating ovaries.  Therefore, symptoms may not be present until the mass reaches a certain size or is discovered incidentally on examination or imaging.  When symptoms are present, they may include pelvic/abdominal pain (unilateral), pelvic pressure, abdominal bloating or distension, dyspareunia, or bladder/bowel symptoms (eg, urinary frequency, constipation) from mass effect.



Acute onset of severe pain with nausea and/or vomiting is concerning for ovarian torsion (

figure 4
), a surgical emergency in which the ovary twists on its ligamentous support, occluding its blood flow.



Early satiety, bloating, and unintentional weight loss are concerning for malignancy.

Diagnostic evaluation

Step 1:  Clinical assessment



The evaluation of an ovarian mass begins with a history, physical examination, and urine pregnancy test.  History should focus on:



  • Onset, duration, and progression of symptoms (eg, pelvic pain, pressure).
  • Associated symptoms (eg, bowel/bladder symptoms, menstrual irregularities, nausea/vomiting, fever/chills, weight loss).
  • Menstrual history (eg, regularity/irregularity, pain with menstruation, use of hormonal contraceptives).
  • Sexual activity (eg, new partners, number of lifetime partners), prior sexually transmitted infections, barrier contraception use.
  • Family history of malignancy.


Physical examination includes:



  • Abdominal examination:  Evaluate for signs of peritonitis (eg, guarding, rebound tenderness) and abdominal distension/ascites (eg, fluid wave).
  • Pelvic examination:  Evaluate the cervix for cervical motion tenderness and abnormal vaginal discharge.  Bimanual examination helps elucidate mass size, location, consistency, mobility, and tenderness.  A rectovaginal examination should also be performed to evaluate for nodularity, which is suggestive of malignancy.
  • Evaluation of lymph nodes and signs of metastatic disease:  Inguinal nodes, as well as the skin around the umbilicus (eg, Sister Mary Joseph nodule indicates advanced metastatic disease), should be assessed.


A urine pregnancy test immediately excludes ectopic pregnancy or corpus luteum cyst as a cause of the ovarian mass.

Step 2:  Imaging studies



The primary imaging modality used to evaluate ovarian masses is transvaginal ultrasonography, which characterizes the ovarian mass and adjacent structures (eg, uterus, peritoneal fluid, adjacent bowel).  Doppler ultrasonography is often used to assess blood flow to bilateral ovaries.



Certain ovarian masses have characteristic features that can lead to a presumptive diagnosis:



  • Teratoma (dermoid cyst) (
    image 3
    ):  May have a variety of appearances and components, including hyperechoic lines (hair), acoustic shadowing, and calcifications (teeth).
  • Follicular cyst:  Thin-walled unilocular cyst with anechoic fluid.
  • Endometrioma (ie, chocolate cyst) (
    image 4
    ):  Chocolate cyst with a homogeneous ground-glass appearance.
  • Hemorrhagic cyst (
    image 5
    ):  Complex cyst containing anechoic fluid with lace-like reticular echoes.


Ultrasonography identifies the need for immediate surgical intervention (eg, torsion [ie, no blood flow], hemoperitoneum).  It also characterizes masses as likely benign or concerning for malignancy based on the following features:



  • Benign features:  Simple, thin-walled, mobile.
  • Malignant features:  Thick septations, solid components, immobile, internal vascularity.


If ultrasonography is inconclusive, an MRI can be used for further characterization.  In patients with suspected ovarian cancer, CT scan of the chest/abdomen/pelvis is used to evaluate for metastases (eg, omental caking, enlarged pelvic/paraaortic lymph nodes, pleural effusions).

Step 3:  Laboratory evaluation



Histologic diagnosis is the only way to definitively diagnose an ovarian mass.  However, because ovarian cancers have the potential to seed the peritoneal cavity (increasing their cancer stage), biopsies are not performed.  Therefore, for ovarian masses without clear, characteristic features on ultrasonography, laboratory evaluation further classifies the mass as either benign or malignant:



  • An hCG screen is always performed in women with ovarian masses to rule out pregnancy-related masses (eg, ectopic pregnancy).
  • Complete blood count may be performed to assess for anemia or infection.
  • Tumor markers can be increased in some ovarian malignancies, and screening may be indicated depending on patient age, symptoms, and imaging findings:
    • Cancer antigen (CA-125):  Nonspecific marker for epithelial ovarian cancers (however, also elevated in benign conditions [eg, endometriosis, pregnancy]).
    • AFP, LDH, and quantitative hCG:  Elevated in germ cell tumors.
    • Inhibin and estradiol:  Elevated in granulosa cell tumors.
    • Testosterone:  Elevated in Sertoli-Leydig tumors.

Management



The management of an ovarian mass depends on the degree of suspicion of malignancy.

Likely benign masses



Observation is preferred for asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic ovarian masses that are likely benign.  Size dictates management for simple cysts:



  • <3-5 cm:  No further imaging.
  • <5 cm:  Surveillance (ie, repeat imaging in several months to ensure stability/resolution).
  • >5 cm:  Ovarian teratomas or endometriomas are typically surgically removed because they are unlikely to resolve, and they increase the risk for torsion or rupture.


For patients with acute presentations (eg, torsion, rupture), surgical management is indicated with ovarian cystectomy (premenopausal) or oophorectomy (postmenopausal).  Tuboovarian abscesses are managed with intravenous antibiotics and may require image-guided drainage.

Indeterminate masses



Indeterminate ovarian masses are often managed with surgery because the prognosis of ovarian cancer is poor unless it is detected and treated early; some patients may elect for surveillance with repeat ultrasonography.  Factors that should prompt surgery include:



  • Masses >10 cm (especially in postmenopausal patients).
  • Symptoms of ovarian cancer (eg, weight loss, bloating, early satiety).
  • Findings suspicious for a germ cell or sex cord–stromal tumor.


After removal of the mass, histologic evaluation determines whether it is benign or malignant and therefore whether it dictates additional management.

Masses suspicious for malignancy



Patients with a high risk for ovarian cancer (eg, hereditary cancer syndrome, ascites, evidence of metastasis, elevated CA-125, characteristic findings on ultrasonography) should undergo surgery by a gynecologic oncologist.  Patients with advanced disease require exploratory laparotomy with tumor debulking followed by chemotherapy.



Details about ovarian cancer can be found in a separate dedicated article.

Summary



Ovarian masses are a common clinical finding and may cause symptoms such as pelvic pain or pressure.  The ultimate goal of the evaluation is to determine the risk for malignancy and reduce the rate of complications (eg, rupture, torsion).  Transvaginal ultrasonography is the primary diagnostic tool, and tumor markers can aid in risk assessment.  Management is dependent on the likelihood of malignancy.
